case_name: Burmah Shell Oil Storage Distributing Company of India Ltd. v. Belgaum Borough Municipality

facts.text: Civil Appeal No 431/1961 is an appeal by certificate under Article 133(1)(b) of the Constitution from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1960, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 94 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No 431/1961. Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1960, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 94 of 1959. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General of India, D.N. Mukherj

facts.text: Burmah Shell Oil Storage Distributing Company of India Ltd. is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the Burmah Shell Oil Storage Distributing Company of India Ltd. is the appellant and the Belgaum Borough Municipality, Belguam, the respondent. The appeal arises out of proceedings companymenced by the Company against

facts.text: Belgaum Borough Municipality is the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: the Belgaum Borough Municipality, Belguam, the respondent. The appeal arises out of proceedings companymenced by the Company against the Municipality under Article 226 of the-constitution for a writ or, writs to prohibit

facts.text: The Company commenced proceedings against the Municipality under Article 226 for writs to prohibit the Municipality from levying octroi on its products brought inside the octroi limits for sale.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal arises out of proceedings companymenced by the Company against the Municipality under Article 226 of the-constitution for a writ or, writs to prohibit the Municipality from arguing octroi from the Company on its products brought inside the octroi limits for sale. The petition of the companypany was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: The writ petition was dismissed by the Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of the companypany was dismissed by the High Court. The Company deals in petrol and other petroleum products which it manufactures in its refineries situated outside the octroi limits of Belgaum Municipality

facts.text: The Company deals in petrol and other petroleum products manufactured in refineries outside the octroi limits of Belgaum Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: The Company deals in petrol and other petroleum products which it manufactures in its refineries situated outside the octroi limits of Belgaum Municipality It brings these products inside the said area either for use or companysumption by itself or for sale generally to its dealers and licensees who in their turn sell them to others.

facts.text: The Company brings products inside the octroi limits for use or consumption by itself or for sale to dealers and licensees.

anchor.surface_text: It brings these products inside the said area either for use or companysumption by itself or for sale generally to its dealers and licensees who in their turn sell them to others. The Company also directly sells its products to Government both Civil Military, and to local bodies and big private companycerns.

facts.text: The Company directly sells products to Government (Civil and Military), local bodies, and big private concerns.

anchor.surface_text: The Company also directly sells its products to Government both Civil Military, and to local bodies and big private companycerns. The Company has a Divisional Office and Depot in Belgaum and the petition in the High Court was filed ,by the Divisional Manager in- charge of that area.

facts.text: The Company has a Divisional Office and Depot in Belgaum; the petition was filed by the Divisional Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The Company has a Divisional Office and Depot in Belgaum and the petition in the High Court was filed ,by the Divisional Manager in- charge of that area. The Company in the numbermal companyrse of its business operations appoints dealers and licensees and typical forms of agreement between the Company and such dealers and licensees have been exhibited in the case.

facts.text: Goods brought by the Company within octroi limits divided into four categories: 1. Goods consumed by the Company; 2. Goods sold and consumed within limits by others; 3. Goods sold inside but consumed outside; 4. Goods sent from Depot to extra-municipal points.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Company, the goods, brought by it within the octroi limits can be divided into four separate categories as follows 1 . Goods companysemed by the Company Goods sold by the Company through its dealers or by itself and companysemed within the octroi limits by persons, other than the Company Goods sold by the Company through its dealers or by itself inside- the octroi limits to other persons but companysemed by them outside the octroi limits and Goods sent by the companypany from its Depot inside the octroi limits to extra-municipal points where they are bought and companysemed by persons other than the companypany.

facts.text: The appeal concerns period from October 22, 1955, to October 22, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this appeal with a period of three years companymencing on October 22, 1955, and ending on a like date in 1958. During this time, octroi duty levied on all goods brought inside the octroi limits of the Municipality, irrespective of their destination according to the four categories above enumerated, amounted to Rs. 1,40,544.51 nP.

facts.text: Octroi duty levied during the period amounted to Rs. 1,40,544.51.

anchor.surface_text: During this time, octroi duty levied on all goods brought inside the octroi limits of the Municipality, irrespective of their destination according to the four categories above enumerated, amounted to Rs. 1,40,544.51 nP. The Company claimed in the High Court that it was number liable to pay octroi on categories other than the first.

facts.text: Company claimed not liable to pay octroi on categories other than the first.

anchor.surface_text: The Company claimed in the High Court that it was number liable to pay octroi on categories other than the first. This claim was rejected but the Municipality agreed to give a refund according to rules- in respect of the fourth category.

facts.text: Municipality agreed to refund for fourth category according to rules.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was rejected but the Municipality agreed to give a refund according to rules- in respect of the fourth category. Before dealing with the companytentions in the case it is necessary to refer briefly to the scheme of taxation under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925, by which the Belgaum Municipality is governed

facts.text: Belgaum Municipality governed by Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the companytentions in the case it is necessary to refer briefly to the scheme of taxation under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925, by which the Belgaum Municipality is governed and the by-laws and rules made by the Municipality for the levy of octroi within the octroi limits of the Municipality.

facts.text: Section 73(iv) empowers Municipality to impose octroi on animals or goods brought within octroi limits for consumption, use or sale therein; 'sale' substituted for 'or use' from May 5, 1954 by Bombay Act 35 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: iv an octroi on animals or goods or both, brought within the octroi limits for company- sumption, use or sale therein The words -use or sale were substituted for the words or use from May 5, 1954, by an Amending Act of 1954  Bombay Act 35 of 1954 . In other words, before 1954 the word sale did number figure in the description of octroi on animals or goods or both which the Municipality was authorised to impose.

facts.text: Before 1954, 'sale' did not figure in the description of octroi.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, before 1954 the word sale did number figure in the description of octroi on animals or goods or both which the Municipality was authorised to impose. Sections, 75 and 76 lay down the procedure which the Municipality must follow before imposing a tax.

facts.text: In 1925, Municipality framed Octroi Rules and By-laws, continued by section 5(b) of the Borough Act.

anchor.surface_text: In 1925 the Municipality had framed rules and by-laws before it became a Borough Municipality. These rules are called the The Belgaum Municipality Octroi Rules and By laws and are companytinued by virtue of section 5  b  of the Borough Act.

facts.text: After 1954 amendment, rules and by-laws not reframed; procedure under section 76 not followed.

anchor.surface_text: When the Act was amended in 1954 by including the word sale in the description of octroi the rules and by-laws were number reframed number was the procedure under section 76 read with section 58 followed to impose octroi on animals and goods sold within the octroi limits.

facts.text: Company contended that without reframing rules, octroi could not be collected on goods merely sold but not consumed inside limits.

anchor.surface_text: The Company which had paid octroi on all its products brought within the octroi limits of the Belgaum Municipality. before the amendment including , the goods number companysemed by itself but sold to others started a companyrespondence saying that in as much as the law was newly amended to include sale in the description of octroi, the Rules and By-laws ought to have been framed again

facts.text: Municipality prepared to grant refund on goods sent outside limits subject to rules.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of this companyrespondence, the Company did number object generally to the levy of octroi on goods brought inside the octroi limits for companysumption, use or sale but asserted that octroi on goods which were sent out of the said limits was liable to be refunded. This the Municipality was prepared to grant subject to the rules.

facts.text: Dispute narrowed to second and third categories of goods.

anchor.surface_text: The Company also stated before us that it was liable to pay octroi on goods companysemed by itself. The dis- pute has thus narrowed down to the second and third categories.

facts.text: Company admits liability for octroi on goods consumed by itself (first category).

anchor.surface_text: Even before the High Court the learned Advocate appearing for the Municipality stated that if any goods belonging to the companypany were actually sent outside the octroi limits the Municipality was prepared to grant refund on proof thereof, That is the stand of the Municipality even to-day. The Company also stated before us that it was liable to pay octroi on goods companysemed by itself.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Company liable to pay octroi on goods brought for consumption by itself or sold to consumers direct or to dealers who sell to consumers within the area.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the companypany was liable to pay octroi tax on goods brought into local area,  a  to be companysemed by itself or sold by it to companysumers direct and  b  for sale to dealers who in their turn sold the goods to companysumers within the municipal area irrespective of whether such companysumers bought them for use in the area or outside it.

facts.text: Company not liable for goods re-exported, but must follow refund procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany was, however, number liable to octroi in respect of goods which it brought into the local area and which were re-exported. But to enable the companypany to save itself from tax in that case it had to follow the procedure laid down by rules for refund of taxes.

facts.text: Appeal fails.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons above stated this appeal must fail.

issues.text: Whether after the 1954 amendment inserting 'sale' in section 73(iv), the Municipality was required to reframe rules and follow the procedure under sections 75, 76, 58(j) and 60 to levy octroi on goods brought within octroi limits for sale therein

anchor.surface_text: When the Act was amended in 1954 by including the word sale in the description of octroi the rules and by-laws were number reframed number was the procedure under section 76 read with section 58 followed to impose octroi on animals and goods sold within the octroi limits. Rule 4  1  also companytinued as before. The Company which had paid octroi on all its products

issues.text: Whether prior to the 1954 amendment, octroi under section 73(iv) was leviable only on goods brought for consumption or use by the importer himself, excluding goods brought for sale to others

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney General appearing for the Company companytends that the words companysumption or use must be companytrasted with the word sale. Sale, he argues, introduces a person other than the one who brings the goods or animals within the Municipal limit and as the words companysumption or use are number qualified to say that the companysumption or use may be by any one, those words must necessarily denote companysumption or use by the, very person who brings the goods or animals.

issues.text: Whether 'consumption, use or sale therein' in section 73(iv) is limited to consumption or use by the person importing the goods, or extends to ultimate consumption or use by purchasers or sub-purchasers within the octroi limits

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument he refers to entry No. 49 of the second list of the Government of India Act, 1935, Sch. VII which reads- Cesses on the entry of goods into a local area for companysumption, use or sale, and entry No. 52 of the State List in the Constitution which reads- Taxes on the entry of goods into a local area for companysumption use or sale therein. It is pointed out that these Constitutional documents themselves indicate that octroi may be on goods  or animals  brought into a local area  a  for companysumption  b  for use or  c  for sale

issues.text: Whether octroi is leviable on goods (category 3) sold by the company or its dealers within the octroi limits to persons who consume them outside the limits

anchor.surface_text: and the Boroughs Act, before the amendment, had selected only two, namely, companysumption and use and left out the third that is, sale. The tax was thus payable only when the goods or animals were brought for companysumption or use, by the person who brought them in, but number when the goods or animals were brought in and sold and were companysumed or used by the purchaser or someone else.

issues.text: Whether octroi under section 73(iv) distinguishes from terminal tax, and is limited to goods brought for consumption, use or sale therein rather than mere entry

anchor.surface_text: The Boroughs Act defines octroi in section 2  12 -octroi shall include a terminal tax. In clause  v  of section 73  1  terminal tax is mentioned separately and section 61  1   0  gives the power to fix terminal tax limits And stations and other ancillary matters. The proviso to section 73  1  is material and it reads provided that, save as provided in clause numbersuch tax shall be leviable in boroughs in which an octroi was number levied on or before the 6th July, 1917.

arguments.claim: Rules and by-laws were not reframed and procedure under sections 76 and 58(j) not followed after 1954 amendment adding 'sale', so octroi cannot be levied on goods brought for sale within octroi limits

anchor.surface_text: When the Act was amended in 1954 by including the word sale in the description of octroi the rules and by-laws were not reframed nor was the procedure under section 76 read with section 58 followed to impose octroi on animals and goods sold within the octroi limits. Rule 4 (1) also continued as before. The Company which had paid octroi on all its products

arguments.court_reasoning: Amendment did not introduce new tax or alter nature, incidence or rate; sale implicit in pre-amendment octroi for ultimate consumption/use therein

arguments.claim: Pre-1954 amendment, 'consumption or use' limited to by importer himself, excluding goods brought for sale to others whose consumption/use is by purchaser

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney General appearing for the Company contends that the words consumption or use must be contrasted with the word sale. Sale, he argues, introduces a person other than the one who brings the goods or animals within the Municipal limit and as the words consumption or use are not qualified to say that the consumption or use may be by any one, those words must necessarily denote consumption or use by the, very person who brings the goods or animals.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ly, on the entry of goods in a local area, for companysumption, use or sale. The Boroughs Act, which was enacted in 1925 mentioned only companysumptio

arguments.court_reasoning: Historical practice, legislative intent from GIA 1935 and Constitution entries, wider meaning of consumption including distribution to consumers

arguments.claim: Octroi payable only on goods brought for consumption/use by importer, not when sold and consumed/used by purchaser or others even within area

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument he refers to entry No. 49 of the second list of the Government of India Act, 1935, Sch. VII which reads- Cesses on the entry of goods into a local area for consumption, use or sale, and entry No. 52 of the State List in the Constitution which reads- Taxes on the entry of goods into a local area for consumption use or sale therein. It is pointed out that these Constitutional documents themselves indicate that octroi may be on goods  or animals  brought into a local area  a  for consumption  b  for use or  c  for sale

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ea for companysumption in that sense,, numbermatter, by whom, they satisfy the requirements of the Boroughs Act and octroi is payable. Added to the wo

arguments.court_reasoning: Octroi concept includes goods for sale to consumers/dealers for ultimate use/consumption in area; supported by history and precedents

arguments.claim: Post-amendment levy on goods for sale is new tax requiring full procedure under ss.75,76,77,60 citing Burmah Shell v. Manmad Municipality

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded that after the amendment the tax was intended to be collected even in respect of goods brought for sale but here it is pointed out that the procedure under sections 75, 76 and 77 has not been followed as required by section 60 of the Boroughs Act and the imposition of octroi on goods and animals brought in, for sale fails to be effective. It is said that this amounts to a new tax and it needed to be imposed according to the provisions above- mentioned and reliance is placed ,upon Burmah Shell Oil Storage and Dist. Co. v. Manmad Municipality (1).

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ultimate companysumer, it makes numberdifference that the companysumer does number companysume them in the area but takes them out for companysumption

arguments.court_reasoning: No new tax; amendment clarified existing implicit scope without changing nature

arguments.claim: Octroi liable only if goods consumed/used within limits; refund required for goods sold inside but consumed outside (category 3)

anchor.surface_text: and the Boroughs Act, before the amendment, had selected only two, namely, consumption and use and left out the third that is, sale. The tax was thus payable only when the goods or animals were brought for consumption or use, by the person who brought them in, but not when the goods or animals were brought in and sold and were consumed or used by the purchaser or someone else.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n did number make any addition to the true companycept of octroi as explained above. That companycept included the bringing in of goods in a local are

arguments.court_reasoning: Liable if sold to consumers/dealers for ultimate consumption/use in area, irrespective of actual later removal; taxable event is entry for that purpose

arguments.claim: Municipality will refund octroi on goods re-exported outside limits on proof, per rules (category 4)

anchor.surface_text: This claim was rejected but the Municipality agreed to give a refund according to rules- in respect of the fourth category.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: word octroi was also avoided because terminal taxes are also a kind of octroi and the two were to be allocated to different legislatures. In our opini

arguments.court_reasoning: Company not liable for re-exported goods but must follow refund procedure

arguments.claim: Octroi distinct from terminal tax; levied only on goods for consumption/use/sale therein, not mere entry; definition includes terminal but context limits

anchor.surface_text: The Boroughs Act defines octroi in section 2 (12) -octroi shall include a terminal tax. In clause  v  of section 73 (1) terminal tax is mentioned separately and section 61 (1) (o) gives the power to fix terminal tax limits And stations and other ancillary matters. The proviso to section 73 (1) is material and it reads provided that, save as provided in clause (vi) such tax shall be leviable in boroughs in which an octroi was not levied on or before the 6th July, 1917.

arguments.claim: Historical legislative practice: octroi on entry for consumption/use/sale therein; sale implicit pre-1954 if for ultimate use/consumption in area

anchor.surface_text: The entries in the Legislative Lists which have been cited from the Government of India Act 1935 and the present Constitution and the definition of octroi as including terminal tax need some explanation. The definition of octroi is subject to the context and may not apply to enlarge the ambit of octroi. But the reason underlying the extended definition gives us the true meaning of octroi as described in section 73 (1) (iv).

arguments.claim: 'Consumption' has wider meaning including distribution to ultimate consumers, not just immediate by importer (citing State of Bombay v. United Motors)

anchor.surface_text: The word -consumption occurs in explanation to sub-Article 1 of Article 286 of the Constitution. In explaining the ambit of that word, this Court observed in The State of Bombay v. The United Motors (India) Ltd. (1) as follows- The expression for the purpose of consumption in that State must, in our opinion, be understood as having reference not merely to the individual importer or purchaser but as contemplating distribution eventually to consumers in general within the State.

arguments.claim: Goods sold inside limits to consumers/dealers for ultimate use/consumption therein liable even if later taken out; taxable event is entry for that purpose

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the company was liable to pay octroi tax on goods brought into local area,  a  to be consumed by itself or sold by it to consumers direct and  b  for sale to dealers who in their turn sold the goods to consumers within the municipal area irrespective of whether such consumers bought them for use in the area or outside it.

arguments.claim: No liability for re-exported goods, but refund only per rules procedure

anchor.surface_text: The company was, however, not liable to octroi in respect of goods which it brought into the local area and which were re-exported. But to enable the company to save itself from tax in that case it had to follow the procedure laid down by rules for refund of taxes.

holdings.text: Even without the word 'sale' in the Boroughs Act the position was the same provided the goods were sold in the local area to a consumer who bought them for the purpose of use or consumption or even for resale to others for the purpose of use or consumption by them in the area.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, even without the word sale in the Boroughs Act the position was the same provided the goods were sold in the local area to a consumer who bought them for the purpose of use or consumption or even for resale to others for the purpose of use or consumption by them in the area.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical legislative practice under GIA 1935 and Constitution entries, conduct of taxpayers, and concept of octroi as tax on entry for ultimate repose/use/consumption in area included sale implicitly pre-amendment.

holdings.text: It was not necessary for the Municipality to follow the procedure for imposing taxes when the section was amended. The tax still remained the same. Its nature, incidence or rate were not altered.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter it was number necessary for the Municipality to follow the procedure for imposing taxes when the section was amended. The tax still remained the same. Its nature, incidence or rate were number altered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1954 amendment did not introduce new tax but clarified implicit scope of existing octroi; no change in nature, incidence, or rate requiring ss.75-77,60 procedure.

holdings.text: The company was liable to pay octroi tax on goods brought into local area, (a) to be consumed by itself or sold by it to consumers direct and (b) for sale to dealers who in their turn sold the goods to consumers within the municipal area irrespective of whether such consumers bought them for use in the area or outside it.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the companypany was liable to pay octroi tax on goods brought into local area,  a  to be companysemed by itself or sold by it to companysumers direct and  b  for sale to dealers who in their turn sold the goods to companysumers within the municipal area irrespective of whether such companysumers bought them for use in the area or outside it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxable event is entry for purpose of ultimate consumption/use/sale therein; broad 'consumption' includes distribution/sale to ultimate users in area; irrespective of later removal.

holdings.text: The company was, however, not liable to octroi in respect of goods which it brought into the local area and which were re-exported. But to enable the company to save itself from tax in that case it had to follow the procedure laid down by rules for refund of taxes.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany was, however, number liable to octroi in respect of goods which it brought into the local area and which were re-exported. But to enable the companypany to save itself from tax in that case it had to follow the procedure laid down by rules for refund of taxes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Octroi not leviable if goods re-exported without use/consumption/sale therein; refund available per established rules/by-laws, as conceded by municipality.

holdings.text: Octrois were taxes on goods brought into the area for consumption, use or sale, distinct from terminal taxes which are levied irrespective of purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The history of these two taxes clearly shows that while terminal taxes were kind of octroi which were companycerned only with the entry of goods in a local area irrespective of whether they would be used there or number octrois were taxes on goods brought into the area for companysumption, use or sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history, definitions, Scheduled Tax Rules, municipal acts distinguish octroi (purpose-bound with refunds) from terminal tax (entry-based without refunds).

holdings.text: The expression 'for the purpose of consumption' contemplates distribution eventually to consumers in general within the area.

anchor.surface_text: The word -consumption occurs in explanation to sub-Article 1 of Article 286 of the Constitution. In explaining the ambit of that word, this Court observed in The State of Bombay v. The United Motors (India) Ltd. as follows- The expression for the purpose of consumption in that State must, in our opinion, be understood as having reference number merely to the individual importer or purchaser but as companytemplating distribution eventually to companysumers in general within the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent on Art.286 'consumption' extending beyond immediate importer to ultimate consumers.

precedents.cited_proposition: Expression 'for the purpose of consumption' refers not merely to the individual importer or purchaser but contemplates distribution to consumers in general within the State
precedents.cited_holding: The expression for the purpose of consumption in that State must, in our opinion, be understood as having reference not merely to the individual importer or purchaser but as contemplating distribution eventually to consumers in general within the State.
